We now introduce a coordinate system that will be extremely useful in string theory, the light-cone coordinates.

The light-cone coordinates can be defined as two independent linear combinations of the time and a chosen spatial coordinate (conventionally x^1x1x^1x1): \begin {align*} x^+ \equiv \frac {1}{ \sqrt {2}} (X^0 + X^1) \\ x^- \equiv \frac {1}{ \sqrt {2}} (X^0 - X^1) \end {align*} x+≡12(X0+X1)x−≡12(X0−X1) \begin {align*} x^+ \equiv \frac {1}{ \sqrt {2}} (X^0 + X^1) \\ x^- \equiv \frac {1}{ \sqrt {2}} (X^0 - X^1) \end {align*} x+≡2​1​(X0+X1)x−≡2​1​(X0−X1)​ while other spatial coordinates remain unchanged. Thus the complete set of light-cone coordinates is (x^+,x^-,x^2,x^3)(x+,x−,x2,x3)(x^+,x^-,x^2,x^3)(x+,x−,x2,x3).

The name light-cone coordinates comes from the fact that the associated coordinates axes are the world-lines of beams of light emitted form the origin along the x^1x1x^1x1 axis. For a beam of light moving in the positive x^1x1x^1x1 direction, we have x^1=ct=x^0x1=ct=x0x^1=ct=x^0x1=ct=x0 and thus x^-=0x−=0x^-=0x−=0. By definition x^-=0x−=0x^-=0x−=0 is actually the x^+x+x^+x+ axis. For a beam of light moving in the negative x^1x1x^1x1 direction, we have x^1=-ct=-x^0x1=−ct=−x0x^1=-ct=-x^0x1=−ct=−x0 and thus x^+=0x+=0x^+=0x+=0. By definition x^+=0x+=0x^+=0x+=0 is actually the x^-x−x^-x− axis. The x^+x+x^+x+ and x^-x−x^-x− axes are perpendicular to each other and at 45^ \circ45∘45^ \circ45∘ to the x^0x0x^0x0 and x^1x1x^1x1 axis.

Both x^+x+x^+x+ and x^-x−x^-x− can be a time coordinate although neither is a time coordinate in the standard sense of the world (Not ordinary time). For definiteness we will take x^+x+x^+x+ as the light-cone time coordinate and x^-x−x^-x− as the spatial coordinate.

A central concept in special relativity is proper time, which is a Lorentz invariant measure of time. Consider a world-line and two events AAAA and BBBB on the world-line. Different Lorentz observers will measure different time intervals between the two events. But imagine a clock that moves along the world-line. The time measured by the clock is called the proper time between the two events.
The proper time along a timelike world-line is defined as the time as measured by a clock following that line.
